    <item>
      <title>Facebook ordered to stop collecting user data by Belgian court</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/16/facebook-ordered-stop-collecting-user-data-fines-belgian-court</link>
      <description><p>Social network instructed to delete illegally collected data or face €100m in fines after it loses case over consent and tracking </p><p>Facebook has been ordered by a Belgian court to stop collecting data on users or face daily fines of €250,000 a day, or up to €100m.</p><p>The court ruled on Friday that Facebook had broken privacy laws by tracking people on third-party sites in the latest salvo in a long-running battle between the Belgian commission for the protection of privacy (CPP) and the social network.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/16/facebook-ordered-stop-collecting-user-data-fines-belgian-court">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Uber to set up 24-hour hotline for UK customers</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/16/uber-set-up-24-hour-incident-hotline-uk-customers-report-police</link>
      <description><p>Taxi-hailing app promises to proactively report any serious incidents to police</p><p>Uber has announced it is to set up a 24-hour hotline for UK customers and will proactively report incidents to the police, a day after London’s transport authorities announced <a draggable="true" href="http://content.tfl.gov.uk/private-hire-policy-statement.pdf">plans for tighter controls</a> on private hire firms.<br tabindex="-1"></p><p>The move also comes ahead of a court of appeal hearing where Transport for London will seek to demand that private hire operators should have a phone line – a regulation quashed by judges after <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/uber">Uber</a> forced a judicial review of taxi regulations in 2016. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/16/uber-set-up-24-hour-incident-hotline-uk-customers-report-police">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The next level of driverless cars: how to solve the problem of humans falling asleep</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/next-level-driverless-cars-how-to-solve-the-problem-of-humans-falling-asleep</link>
      <description><p>Next wave of development will see drivers only expected to intervene when the car requests it, say researchers</p><p>Driving down the motorway in a swanky semi-autonomous car, the vehicle is at its own wheel, humming along smoothly. But coming off a slip road it is over to you. The only trouble is, you’ve fallen asleep. </p><p>The goal of a completely driverless car is considered top of <a draggable="true" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_car#Levels_of_driving_automation">a six-level scale of autonomy</a>, and researchers believe it will one day be possible to achieve that aim. But for now, cars are stuck at level two on the scale – in which the driver must still perform several key aspects of driving – while engineers work out how to crack the problem of keeping drivers alert. <br tabindex="-1"></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/next-level-driverless-cars-how-to-solve-the-problem-of-humans-falling-asleep">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>US joins UK in blaming Russia for NotPetya cyber-attack</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/uk-blames-russia-notpetya-cyber-attack-ukraine</link>
      <description><p>White House labels Kremlin ‘reckless’, while UK says it ‘undermined democracy’</p><p>The US and UK governments have publicly blamed Russia for a crippling cyber-attack last year that targeted <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/ukraine">Ukraine</a> and spread around the world.</p><p>On Thursday, Sarah Sanders, the White House press secretary, said that the <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jun/27/petya-ransomware-attack-strikes-companies-across-europe">NotPetya ransomware attack</a> in June 2017 “was part of the Kremlin’s ongoing effort to destabilise Ukraine and demonstrates ever more clearly Russia’s involvement in the ongoing conflict.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/uk-blames-russia-notpetya-cyber-attack-ukraine">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Can we really trust Google as judge, jury and executioner of online ads?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/google-chrome-adblocking-online-ads</link>
      <description><p>With cries of undue influence over the industry body deciding which ads to ban, is new Chrome adblocking too self-serving?</p><p>From today, users of Google Chrome, the most popular web browser in the world, will <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/google-adblocker-chrome-browser">no longer see 12 types of online adverts</a> which have been deemed to be “intrusive” by a group of advertising industry members</p><p>Leading that body, which examined 104 potential formats to determine which should be blocked and which should be allowed, is the world’s largest digital advertiser: Google.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/google-chrome-adblocking-online-ads">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'Don’t tell me to oil my wood': users angry at marks left by Apple HomePod</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/white-ring-marks-apple-homepod-smart-speaker</link>
      <description><p>White rings formed due to oils and polish in the wood reacting negatively with the silicone foot on the bottom of £319 speaker</p><p>Early adopters of Apple’s new £319 HomePod smart speaker have started complaining that the “new sound of home” is leaving white ring marks on wooden surfaces that are difficult to remove.<br></p><p>One user tweeted Apple that the new speaker left “etched circles” on their wooden furniture within 20 minutes of use, while others found the speaker left deeper and more obvious marks in several places and on several different types of wooden surface.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/white-ring-marks-apple-homepod-smart-speaker">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>As Peter Thiel ditches Silicon Valley for LA, locals tout 'conservative renaissance'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/16/peter-thiel-silicon-valley-move-la-conservatives-welcome</link>
      <description><p>The outspoken libertarian’s departure is a sign of the times, say LA conservatives, as Silicon Valley faces criticism for silencing alternative viewpoints</p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/22/peter-thiel-paypal-donald-trump-silicon-valley-libertarian">The only living Trump supporter in Silicon Valley</a><br></li></ul><p>If the billionaire tech investor and noted libertarian Peter Thiel <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/tech-luminary-peter-thiel-parts-ways-with-silicon-valley-1518696120">really does leave</a> Silicon Valley for Los Angeles to escape what he views as an increasing intolerance for conservatives, the city’s growing community of conservatives will be there to welcome him.</p><p>Among LA’s right-leaning residents are the Daily Wire’s Ben Shapiro, the political commentator Dave Rubin and the blogger Bill Whittle. There’s also the former members of the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/apr/21/secretive-hollywood-conservative-group-dissolves-trump">defunct Friends of Abe</a>, a secretive group of Hollywood conservatives that fractured in 2016 over the candidacy of Donald Trump.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/16/peter-thiel-silicon-valley-move-la-conservatives-welcome">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Apple bug crashes apps that display Telugu character</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/16/apple-bug-crashes-apps-that-display-telegu-character</link>
      <description><p>Company is working to fix glitch in software update that can put devices into bootloop</p><p>Apple is working urgently to fix a bug in its latest software update that crashes applications that display a particular letter from the south Indian language Telugu.</p><p>Typing or receiving a message that contains the letter causes apps such as Gmail, Instagram or WhatsApp to crash.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/16/apple-bug-crashes-apps-that-display-telegu-character">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Google turns on default adblocker within Chrome</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/google-adblocker-chrome-browser</link>
      <description><p>Users of latest Chrome browser on Windows, Mac OS, Linux and Android will have some of most intrusive types of ads blocked automatically</p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/google-chrome-adblocking-online-ads">Comment: Can we really trust Google as judge, jury and executioner of online ads?</a><br></li></ul><p>Google will start automatically blocking intrusive ads within its Chrome browser for desktop and Android from Thursday 15 February.<br tabindex="-1"></p><p>The change, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/jun/02/google-build-adblocker-intrusive-ads-chrome-browser">announced in June</a>, will see the dominant browser that is used by <a href="http://gs.statcounter.com/">over 56% of internet users</a> block some of the most intrusive ads including full-page prestitial ads, flashing animated ads and auto-playing video ads with sound.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/google-adblocker-chrome-browser">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/chrome">Chrome</category>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/media/media">Media</category>

      <title>Huge cryptojacking campaign earns just $24 for hackers</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/14/cryptojacking-campaign-24-dollars-hackers-cryptocurrency-salon</link>
      <description><p>Though 5,000-site attack suggests forcing visitors to mine cryptocurrency offers scant reward, it hasn’t stopped news platform Salon</p><p>A malware attack that turned thousands of websites into cryptocurrency mining engines made just $24, according to the company that develops the software used.</p><p>On Sunday, hackers <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/11/government-websites-hit-by-cryptocurrency-mining-malware">compromised an accessibility plugin</a>, BrowseAloud, which is used to offer screen-reading services on a number of websites including the Information Commissioner’s Office, the Student Loans Company and several English councils.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/14/cryptojacking-campaign-24-dollars-hackers-cryptocurrency-salon">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Child development experts urge Facebook to pull Messenger Kids app</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/jan/30/messenger-kids-facebook-mark-zuckerberg-app-child-development-experts-</link>
      <description><p>Open letter signed by more than 100 advocates warns of dangers social media poses to under 13s and asks Mark Zuckerberg to halt app </p><p>More than 110 child-health advocates have called on Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg to pull the firm’s <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/dec/04/messenger-kids-facebook-launches-under-13-chat-app-parental-contact-approval">Messenger Kids </a>app aimed at under 13s, warning of the dangers of social media for children.</p><p>In <a href="http://www.commercialfreechildhood.org/sites/default/files/devel-generate/gaw/FBMessengerKids.pdf">an open letter</a> led by the Boston-based Campaign for Commercial-Free Childhood, signed by doctors, educators and child health experts including baroness <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/susan-greenfield">Susan Greenfield</a>, warn that “younger children are simply not ready to have social media accounts”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/jan/30/messenger-kids-facebook-mark-zuckerberg-app-child-development-experts-">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Is it worth buying a refurbished PC for under £150?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/askjack/2018/feb/15/is-it-worth-buying-cheap-budget-refurbished-desktop-pc-computer</link>
      <description><p>Mark needs to replace a 10-year-old desktop computer on a budget. Is a refurbished model a good option?</p><p>I’m considering buying a new general-purpose home computer for $200 [£142] or less, and I’d like a mini-tower that I can easily repair and upgrade.</p><p>I will use it on the web, to scan photographs (with a flatbed scanner), and to watch video recordings from my trail cameras. I’d like to buy the minimum PC that can handle these tasks significantly faster than my 10-year-old <a href="https://www.lifewire.com/dell-dimension-b110-832018">Dell Dimension B110</a>. I think I’d be happy with a 64-bit Intel Core 2 Duo.</p><p>Many people are familiar with the idea of “fleet cars” that have been bought or leased by large corporations and replaced after two or three years. They are cheap and have generally been well maintained, which makes them popular in the second hand market. There’s a similar market in “fleet computers”, which are usually recycled after three years and sold as refurbished PCs.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/askjack/2018/feb/15/is-it-worth-buying-cheap-budget-refurbished-desktop-pc-computer">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How can I control my child’s social media use?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/askjack/2018/feb/08/how-can-i-control-child-social-media-use-instagram-gmail-accounts</link>
      <description><p>Julia has a problem with her 14-year-old son’s use of Instagram and Gmail and would like to take control of his accounts</p><p>Why do social media sites such as Instagram, Twitter, Facebook etc deem children ‘adults’ in the vast and dangerous world of technology? My 14-year-old is engaging in a toxic relationship with a girl on Instagram. I am not allowed access to his account as it is protected by their user privacy protection agreement. How can a mother have their child’s account removed?<br></p><p>Earlier, I helped my son create a Gmail account for school purposes. I was not aware back then that there was something called Google Family Link. He used the account without any problems for years, but he has changed the password. There is explicit content in his emails that I need to get access to. As with Instagram, I cannot contact anyone at Google via phone, live chat etc, and helpful links keep sending me around in circles. How can I take back the account I created? <strong>Julia</strong></p><p>The British government sets a minimum age for some things, such as drinking, driving and voting. It doesn’t have a minimum age for online activities. According to Ofcom (2015), 67% of five to seven year olds, 91% of eight to 11 year olds and 98% of 12 to 15 year olds use online services, and there are “walled garden” services – <a href="http://www.moshimonsters.com/home/">Moshi Monsters</a>, <a href="https://www.clubpenguinisland.com/">Disney Club Penguin</a>, <a href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/cbeebies">CBeebies</a> – that target much younger users than your son.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/askjack/2018/feb/08/how-can-i-control-child-social-media-use-instagram-gmail-accounts">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/askjack/2018/feb/01/will-i-be-able-to-do-more-work-computer-three-screens-multiple-monitors</link>
      <description><p>Having more screen space makes people more productive, but it’s not necessarily best distributed over multiple monitors</p><p>Will I be able to do more work with three monitors? <strong>Jean</strong></p><p><a href="https://www.bakkerelkhuizen.co.uk/uploads/wysiwyg/Optimal%20performance%20with%20two%20or%20more%20computer%20screens%20UK.pdf">Research</a> shows that people can get more work done if they have more screen area available, and using multiple monitors is a simple way to double or triple your workspace. However, that doesn’t mean having three screens is the best option for you or anyone else. The final decision depends on the way you work, the programs you run, the amount of desk space you have available, and how much you are willing to spend.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/askjack/2018/feb/01/will-i-be-able-to-do-more-work-computer-three-screens-multiple-monitors">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>What can I do to protect my PC from the Meltdown and Spectre flaws?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/askjack/2018/jan/25/what-can-i-do-to-protect-my-pc-from-meltdown-spectre-flaws</link>
      <description><p>John has an old Sony Vaio PC that seems unlikely to receive a firmware update. Should he replace it?</p><p>My Microsoft Surface Book is protected against the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/jan/04/meltdown-spectre-worst-cpu-bugs-ever-found-affect-computers-intel-processors-security-flaw">Meltdown and Spectre</a> security flaws, but my Sony Vaio Pro remains vulnerable to Spectre. Both laptops run Windows 10 and have been updated via Windows Update. The Surface Book’s BIOS has also been updated by Microsoft, but there is no BIOS update for the Vaio – and, I suspect, for millions of other machines.</p><p>What is the risk of continuing to run the Vaio with this known critical vulnerability? Is there another way to mitigate it? Or, in the end, do thousands of people have to dump otherwise good machines and buy new ones?<strong> John Piatt</strong></p><p>It’s too soon to say. Bear in mind that, so far, there are no known exploits for these vulnerabilities, so the current level of risk is low. Companies will try to defend against threats as and when they appear. In the short term, we’ll just have to see how well that goes.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/askjack/2018/jan/25/what-can-i-do-to-protect-my-pc-from-meltdown-spectre-flaws">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>'Parents killed it': why Facebook is losing its teenage users</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/16/parents-killed-it-facebook-losing-teenage-users</link>
      <description><p>This year more than 3 million under-25s in the UK and US are expected to leave the site</p><p>When Mark Zuckerberg <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2007/jul/25/media.newmedia">launched Facebook he was a 19-year-old</a> living in a dorm in his second year at university. Fast-forward 14 years and it is the young people he was so successful in luring to Facebook to propel it to become the world’s biggest social networking site that are now his biggest problem. </p><p>This year more than 3 million under-25s in the UK and US <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/12/is-facebook-for-old-people-over-55s-flock-in-as-the-young-leave">will either quit Facebook or stop using it regularly,</a> and they are pretty vocal about why. <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/16/parents-killed-it-facebook-losing-teenage-users">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Should I call out my friends for using their phones while driving?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/13/driving-talking-phone-advice</link>
      <description><p>There’s no question that ‘distracted driving’ can be deadly – so why are so many of us reluctant to take a stand against it?</p><p><strong>A friend drove me to work the other day and, while she was driving, picked up a call on her cellphone. It was a short conversation and after she hung up, she apologized, but the episode left me feeling uncomfortable. Should I have called her out or am I overreacting?</strong></p><p>I suspect you don’t need me to tell you that your nervousness is well-founded: the statistics on car accidents and phone use are incontrovertible. In 2015, approximately 3,477 people were killed, and 391,000 were injured, in car crashes caused by “distracted driving”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/13/driving-talking-phone-advice">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>Ongoing studies show that some mammals and birds can mimic the sound of the human voice<p>Research <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/jan/31/orcas-killer-whales-can-imitate-human-speech-research-reveals" title="">published last month</a> proved that orca, or killer, whales have the ability to mimic the complexities of human speech. Josep Call, professor in evolutionary origins of mind at the University of St Andrews, was a co-author of the study. He said: “I think here we have the first evidence that killer whales may be learning sounds by vocal imitation.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/10/talking-animals-species-capable-of-speech-mimic-human-voice">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>iPhone X review: Apple finally knocks it out of the park</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/nov/10/iphone-x-review-apple-face-id-all-screen-design-home-button</link>
      <description><p>The company’s most important smartphone in years does not disappoint, with Face ID and an all-screen design that spells the end of the home button </p><p>The iPhone X is Apple’s most important – and most expensive – new smartphone in four years, bringing with it a significant change to the design, dumping the home button to usher in a full-screen experience. Thankfully, Apple nailed it.<br></p><p>After four years of the company recycling the design of the iPhone 6, the iPhone X is a breath of fresh air. The beautiful OLED screen takes up pretty much the whole front of the device. It’s one of the best displays I’ve ever seen on a smartphone, and while it’s not quite as bezel free at the sides as <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/apr/21/samsung-galaxy-s8-review-smartphone-infinity-display-iris-scanner">Samsung’s Galaxy S8</a> and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/sep/07/samsung-galaxy-note-8-review-a-greatest-hits-package-from-the-godfather-of-phablets">Note 8</a> devices, it’s a giant leap forward for Apple.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/nov/10/iphone-x-review-apple-face-id-all-screen-design-home-button">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/sonos-one-review-best-smart-speaker-audiophiles-amazon-alexa</link>
      <description><p>The company’s first foray into smart tech adds Amazon’s Alexa to a great wireless speaker to create a formidable combo</p><p>Having practically invented the multi-room wireless speaker category in 2005, Sonos has lagged behind in the race to become smart. Now the Sonos One is here, packing Alexa in the top and premium audio in the bottom.<br></p><p>The Sonos One is very deliberately designed to look, feel and sound like the company’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/oct/14/sonos-play-1-review">successful Play: 1</a> – a compact wireless speaker launched in 2013 at about £150 that was arguably the best for the money for years. Side-by-side they look identical apart from the top of the speaker, which is flat on the One, perforated by holes for the microphones that enable the voice assistant to hear you.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/sonos-one-review-best-smart-speaker-audiophiles-amazon-alexa">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/13/apple-homepod-review-siri-best-sounding-smart-speaker</link>
      <description><p>It’s the wifi speaker to beat in terms of audio but being locked in to Apple services is frustrating and its voice assistant is lacking </p><p>After much anticipation, and speculation that Apple has missed the boat and handed victory to Amazon’s champion Echo, the HomePod smart speaker is finally here. But is it actually any good? And why exactly does it cost four times as much as an Echo?<br tabindex="-1"></p><p>The HomePod is a voice-controlled speaker that listens out for its wake word “Hey, Siri” and then starts streaming what you say to Apple to interpret your commands and play whatever it is you wish. The fabric-covered cylinder stands an <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/nov/10/iphone-x-review-apple-face-id-all-screen-design-home-button">iPhone X</a>-and-a-bit tall (172mm) with a diameter of an iPhone X (142mm), weighing 2.5kg (14.4 times the iPhone X).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/13/apple-homepod-review-siri-best-sounding-smart-speaker">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/audio/2018/feb/16/mind-the-gap-tech-help-disabled-people-chips-with-everything-podcast</link>
      <description><p>Can technology provide solutions to the various difficulties that disabled people face every day in areas where full accessibility is lacking?</p><p><strong>Subscribe and review on <a href="https://itunes.apple.com/gb/podcast/chips-with-everything/id270424643?mt=2">Apple</a>, <a href="https://open.spotify.com/show/3FvGipVeW868RI1qpScrPo">Spotify</a> or on your favourite podcasting app and join the discussion on <a href="https://www.facebook.com/GuardianPodcasts/">Facebook</a> and <a href="https://twitter.com/guardianaudio">Twitter</a>.</strong><br></p><p>Anyone who uses the London Underground will recognise the monotonous tone of the robotic voice that tells us all to “mind the gap”. Transport organisations around the world use similar systems, hoping passengers will keep their eyes and ears open for long enough to avoid injury.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/audio/2018/feb/16/mind-the-gap-tech-help-disabled-people-chips-with-everything-podcast">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Why Silicon Valley billionaires are prepping for the apocalypse in New Zealand</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/news/2018/feb/15/why-silicon-valley-billionaires-are-prepping-for-the-apocalypse-in-new-zealand</link>
      <description><p>How an extreme libertarian tract predicting the collapse of liberal democracies – written by Jacob Rees-Mogg’s father – inspired the likes of Peter Thiel to buy up property across the Pacific<br></p><p>If you’re interested in the end of the world, you’re interested in New Zealand. If you’re interested in how our current cultural anxieties – climate catastrophe, decline of transatlantic political orders, resurgent nuclear terror – manifest themselves in apocalyptic visions, you’re interested in the place occupied by this distant archipelago of apparent peace and stability against the roiling unease of the day.</p><p>If you’re interested in the end of the world, you would have been interested, soon after Donald Trump’s election as US president, to read a New York Times headline stating that Peter Thiel, the billionaire venture capitalist who co-founded PayPal and was an early investor in Facebook, considered New Zealand to be “the Future”. Because if you are in any serious way concerned about the future, you’re also concerned about Thiel, a canary in capitalism’s coal mine who also happens to have profited lavishly from his stake in the mining concern itself.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/news/2018/feb/15/why-silicon-valley-billionaires-are-prepping-for-the-apocalypse-in-new-zealand">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How an ex-YouTube insider investigated its secret algorithm</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/02/youtube-algorithm-election-clinton-trump-guillaume-chaslot</link>
      <description><p>The methodology Guillaume Chaslot used to detect videos YouTube was recommending during the election – and how the Guardian analysed the data</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/02/how-youtubes-algorithm-distorts-truth">Read the story: how YouTube’s algorithm distorts truth</a></li></ul><p>YouTube’s recommendation system draws on techniques in <a draggable="true" href="https://static.googleusercontent.com/media/research.google.com/en//pubs/archive/45530.pdf">machine learning</a> to decide which videos are auto-played or appear “up next”. The precise formula it uses, however, is kept secret. Aggregate data revealing which YouTube videos are heavily promoted by the algorithm, or how many views individual videos receive from “up next” suggestions, is also withheld from the public.<br tabindex="-1"></p><p>Disclosing that data would enable academic institutions, fact-checkers and regulators (as well as journalists) to assess the type of content YouTube is most likely to promote. By keeping the algorithm and its results under wraps, YouTube ensures that any patterns that indicate unintended biases or distortions associated with its algorithm are concealed from public view.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/02/youtube-algorithm-election-clinton-trump-guillaume-chaslot">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'Fiction is outperforming reality': how YouTube's algorithm distorts truth</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/02/how-youtubes-algorithm-distorts-truth</link>
      <description><p>An ex-YouTube insider reveals how its recommendation algorithm promotes divisive clips and conspiracy videos. Did they harm Hillary Clinton’s bid for the presidency?</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/02/youtube-algorithm-election-clinton-trump-guillaume-chaslot">The methodology behind this story</a></li></ul><p> It was one of January’s most viral videos. Logan Paul, a YouTube celebrity, stumbles across a dead man hanging from a tree. The 22-year-old, who is in a Japanese forest famous as a suicide spot, is visibly shocked, then amused. “Dude, his hands are purple,” he says, before turning to his friends and giggling. “You never stand next to a dead guy?”</p><p>Paul, who has 16 million mostly teen subscribers to his YouTube channel, removed the video from YouTube 24 hours later amid a furious backlash. It was still long enough for the footage to receive 6m views and a spot on YouTube’s coveted list of trending videos.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/02/how-youtubes-algorithm-distorts-truth">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/jan/17/apple-bus-attack-pellet-guns-silicon-valley</link>
      <description><p>Corporate buses, which ferry workers from San Francisco to its Silicon Valley headquarters, have become symbols of gentrification</p><p>At least five buses used to transport <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/apple">Apple</a> employees to the company’s headquarters have had their windows smashed by what is suspected to be pellet guns during the last week.</p><p>The first window was shattered on the evening of Friday 12 January, as the shuttle bus travelled from the company campus back into San Francisco. Three more were hit on Tuesday morning, followed by another suspected attack on Tuesday evening, according to an email sent to Apple staff and seen by the Guardian.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/jan/17/apple-bus-attack-pellet-guns-silicon-valley">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Dead Space was to games what Alien was to movies</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/games/2018/feb/16/dead-space-was-to-games-what-alien-was-to-movies</link>
      <description><p>Now available free on PC, Dead Space came closer than any other game to replicating the look, feel and atmosphere of Ridley Scott’s sci-fi thriller</p><p>This week, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/sep/05/andrew-wilson-of-ea-we-never-want-to-be-worst-us-company-again">Electronic Arts</a> has made one of the most interesting and atmospheric narrative games of the 2000s available for free to users of its Origin gaming service. Released in 2008 and created by Californian studio Visceral Games, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2008/oct/16/microsoft-dead-space">Dead Space</a> remains a heady, often terrifying thrill ride and if you’ve never played it before, it’s worth taking this chance – especially if you’re a fan of the Alien movies.</p><p>Although there have been numerous attempts to bring Alien directly to video games – most successfully, Creative Assembly’s incredibly tense Alien: Isolation – it’s Dead Space that has got closest to replicating the look, feel and atmosphere of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/oct/21/alien-birth-hurt-chestburster">Ridley Scott’s original film</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/games/2018/feb/16/dead-space-was-to-games-what-alien-was-to-movies">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Kingdom Come: Deliverance review – impressively detailed medieval life sim</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/games/2018/feb/15/kingdom-come-deliverance-review-medieval-rpg</link>
      <description><p><strong>PC, PlayStation 4, Xbox One; Warhorse Studios/Koch Media<br></strong>This lush and dynamic RPG prides itself on the historical accuracy of its recreation of 15th-century feudal Bohemia</p><p>Kingdom Come: Deliverance describes itself as a realistic and historically accurate role-playing game, which are dangerous words for any game to throw around. History, like beauty, is often in the eye of the beholder, while “realistic” should indicate more than just “visually detailed”. Kingdom Come: Deliverance’s version of historical realism is obsessive in certain areas, but curiously neglectful in others.<br></p><p>The epic, if familiar, narrative centres around Henry, a blacksmith’s son living in 15th-century Bohemia. Young Hal’s life is flung into chaos after a power spat between the king and his brother results in his village being torched and his parents being murdered. Fleeing with nothing but the last sword his father made, he embarks upon a quest for vengeance that sees him claw his way up the rigid social hierarchy of medieval Europe.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/games/2018/feb/15/kingdom-come-deliverance-review-medieval-rpg">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why it's too soon to classify gaming addiction as a mental disorder</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/head-quarters/2018/feb/14/gaming-addiction-as-a-mental-disorder-its-premature-to-pathologise-players</link>
      <description><p>Concerns over the addictive properties of video games are reasonable but there is a lack of rigorous research behind the WHO’s expected classification</p><p>Video games played on smartphones, tablets, computers and consoles have been a popular form of leisure for some time now. In Europe, <a href="http://www.isfe.eu/sites/isfe.eu/files/gametrack_european_summary_data_2016_q4.pdf">recent figures indicate</a> that games are played by more than two thirds of children and adolescents, and a substantial number of adults now play games – 38% in the UK, 64% in France, 56% in Germany and 44% in Spain.<br></p><p>The WHO will publish the next revision of its manual – the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-11) – by mid-2018 and gaming disorder has been <a href="http://www.who.int/features/qa/gaming-disorder/en/">included in the draft</a> for the first time.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/head-quarters/2018/feb/14/gaming-addiction-as-a-mental-disorder-its-premature-to-pathologise-players">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Crossing Souls review – fun Stranger Things-style nostalgia for the 80s</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/games/2018/feb/13/crossing-souls-review-fun-stranger-things-style-nostalgia-80s</link>
      <description><p><strong>Fourattic/Devolver Digital; PlayStation 4, PC, PlayStation Vita<br></strong>There is nothing original about this Kickstarter-funded game with a plucky Goonies-style gang of 2D characters – but that is the point</p><p>When Crossing Souls’ protagonist wakes up in his pixelated bedroom, it’s not exactly difficult to divine which decade we’re in. The walls are adorned with posters of Ghostbusters and the now-defunct space shuttle. A clunky gaming console sits by a box-shaped TV. An artificial, fizzy green drink has spilled on the wooden floor. This is most definitely the 1980s. Crossing Souls’ chief ambition is to evoke nostalgia, and that goal it is evident in everything it does.</p><p>In the summer of 1986, the blue-haired main character, Chris, leads a band of four school friends around their California hometown. They are a Spielberg cliché: the geeky inventor-type, the annoying but lovable younger brother, the chubby one with a big heart, and the red-haired kickass girl. The chums come across a mysterious ancient artefact that will turn their sheltered suburban lives upside down. Soon they’re battling the forces of evil, crossing dimensions and even travelling through time.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/games/2018/feb/13/crossing-souls-review-fun-stranger-things-style-nostalgia-80s">Continue reading...</a></description>
